programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Dive in Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Shibuya – The Labyrinth Nestled Within a Valley

programme.title: KABUKI KOOL

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: A Device That Improves Children's Vision: Ishigaki Yo / Design Engineer / Professor, The University of Electro-Communications
programme.desc: Amblyopia is a condition where vision in one eye doesn't properly develop. Ishigaki Yo has created a device that improves vision through gaming. He talks about designing products that benefit society.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: laser flaw inspection systems.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Halting Desertification with Waste: Oyama Shuichi / Professor, Research Institute for Humanity and Nature / Kyoto University Graduate School
programme.desc: The majority of Niger, in Africa, is occupied by the Sahara, and desertification is a major problem. Oyama Shuichi introduces his method of increasing vegetation using household waste.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony
programme.desc: Winter in Japan's oldest private herb garden in Uda, Nara Prefecture. As fallen leaves and withered grass cover the ground, the search begins for treasures hidden beneath the frozen soil.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: Edo was a city of waterways. The Yoroi Ferry transported people across the Nihonbashi River, one of its main commercial arteries. For the captain, it was a high-pressure job requiring skill and guts. *"The Yoroi Ferry" from the series "Fine Views of Edo" (1835-39) by Utagawa Hiroshige

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: A Quantum Search for Optimal Solutions
programme.desc: Quantum computers are poised to play a vital role in addressing societal issues. In this episode, we meet two researchers whose work helped lead toward quantum computers becoming a reality.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS
programme.desc: Much of the stonework supporting Japan's terraced fields is in danger of collapse. There's an urgent need to train new stonemasons to carry out repairs. Kaneko Reo runs workshops around the country.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony #5
programme.desc: In Uda, discover Japan's oldest private medicinal herb garden, where the natural landscape from 300 years ago is preserved in a botanical time capsule, a sanctuary of the local culture and history.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: We visit an Edo-style open-air teahouse, where the townspeople enjoyed refreshments, conversation ... and the company of exotic birds. For them, these outings were about more than a good time.

programme.title: Japan Railway Journal
programme.sub-title: Vertical Separation: A Key to the Survival of Local Railways
programme.desc: Amid financial struggles, local railways are increasingly turning to vertical separation (dividing the ownership of infrastructure and operations) in order to survive. See how it works in practice.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: The San'in Kaigan Geopark Trail is a 230-kilometer-long course connecting the Sea of Japan coastline along Tottori, Hyogo, and Kyoto prefectures, which were designated as a UNESCO Global Geopark. Canadian actor Kyle Card dives into the dynamic landscapes—veritable museums of topography and geology where traces of Earth from 30 million years ago remain—and the way of life in old fishing villages.

programme.title: DEEPER LOOK
programme.sub-title: Yoshiki: The Journey to Global Icon. Yoshiki, Cultural Icon.
programme.desc: Yoshiki, the Japanese icon, reflects on how he bridges Japanese and US cultures through his music, fashion, and film.

programme.title: Dig More Japan
programme.desc: The youth of Japan give their all to school activities and their dreams for the future.We dig a little deeper. The segments featured in this episode are available in full online at NHK WORLD-JAPAN ON DEMAND. *Please note that due to the available terms of the video, some of the links may be expired.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef Mini
programme.desc: Dining with the Chef Mini introduces traditional techniques and resourceful recipes in just 5 minutes! Chefs Saito and Rika present their unique approaches to cooking delicious Japanese food. In this episode, chef Rika will teach you how to make Chakin sushi, which consists of sushi rice carefully wrapped in thinly fried egg, often served on festive occasions. Join us and learn how to make Chakin sushi at home!

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef
programme.sub-title: Authentic Japanese Cooking: Udon in Egg-drop Soup
programme.desc: Learn about Japanese home cooking with Master Chef Saito, based on traditional Japanese cooking techniques! Featured recipes: (1) Udon in Egg-drop Soup (2) Salmon with Tofu Wasabi Dressing.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Wastewater Research for Public Health: Kitajima Masaaki / Project Professor, Research Center for Water Environment Technology, The University of Tokyo
programme.desc: In 2020, Kitajima Masaaki published the world's first paper on how the spread of COVID-19 could be tracked by monitoring wastewater. He talks about making an impact on infectious disease control.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony
programme.desc: Autumn in Japan's oldest private medicinal herb garden in Uda, Nara Prefecture. As the plants bear fruit, the garden's custodians protect the seeds, ensuring that they live on for future generations.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Night of Fashion and Fireworks
programme.desc: For a time during the Edo period, fireworks lit up the skies practically every night in the summer. It was a chance for women to dress up and let loose ... and grab the attention of male suitors. *"Women Watching Fireworks at Sumida River" (1795-96) by Kitagawa Utamaro

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Inside the 'Black Box' Hospital: Hidden Crisis in Japan's Psychiatric Care
programme.desc: The former director of Michinoku Kinen Hospital in Aomori Prefecture and his doctor brother were arrested for trying to cover up a killing inside the facility in February. The hospital takes in many patients who other hospitals wouldn't accept. The case exposed a string of irregularities, such as death certificates that were signed by doctors reportedly impaired by dementia. Against the backdrop of an aging society, we look into why the hospital found itself in a situation where family wishes were disregarded, and patients' human rights were routinely ignored. Guest: Takagi Shunsuke (Psychiatrist)

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: Praying for Blue Skies at Tokyo's Weather Shrine
programme.desc: A shrine in Tokyo is dedicated to a deity believed to control the weather. For three days in fall, a season of fickle weather in Japan, we asked people why they wanted divine help for sunny skies.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Love, Anger, and Okinawa: Ishikawa Mao / Photographer
programme.desc: Ishikawa Mao is an award-winning photographer who has been documenting the lives of people in Okinawa for 50 years. She talks about what she wants to express through her work.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony #5
programme.desc: In Uda, discover Japan's oldest private medicinal herb garden, where the natural landscape from 300 years ago is preserved in a botanical time capsule, a sanctuary of the local culture and history.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: We visit an Edo-style open-air teahouse, where the townspeople enjoyed refreshments, conversation ... and the company of exotic birds. For them, these outings were about more than a good time.

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.sub-title: Survivors: Capturing Life After the Atomic Bomb
programme.desc: Tsuchida Hiromi has photographed the everyday lives of people who survived the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, decades apart. Now, 80 years after the bombing, what fresh realities will he capture?

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hi! It's me, Tama! What do I do when I eat too much? I just nibble on some leaves. They're gentle on the stomach. Speaking of leaves, Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko went to see the autumn colors. That reminds me of a seasonal chestnut sweet called kuri-yose! I'm getting hungry again!

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.sub-title: History Uncovered: A Message in Clay
programme.desc: From the 3rd to the early 7th century, Japan produced terracotta figures known as haniwa in many forms. These mysterious objects hold the key to Japan's birth as a unified nation.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: This episode focuses on kuruma, which means both wheel and wheeled vehicle. A ubiquitous word, it has rolled its way into many Japanese expressions.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: On New Year's Eve, performers dress as terrifying monsters called namahage. They barge into people's homes, condemning laziness and frightening children. But this good-natured tradition strengthens family and community bonds. In Tayazawa, a small village in Akita Prefecture, the practice came to an end several years ago, but was recently restarted by an enthusiastic group of locals. They made costumes and succeeded in reviving a custom at risk of slipping away.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: JAPAN DELISH
programme.desc: Japan's longest-loved noodle dish, udon. Savor its undeniable appeal through local favorites and cutting-edge creations!

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: #34 Ensuring a Safe Journey in Japan
programme.desc: The number of foreign visitors to Japan has been on the rise since the COVID travel restrictions have been lifted. However, many are not fully aware of natural disasters that strike Japan such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and typhoons. Now, there are efforts to ensure the safety of visitors during disasters. The newly developed "announcer drone" translates text into 29 languages and instructs people to evacuate while flying. At evacuation centers, local governments are well prepared to notify important information to those who do not understand Japanese, using translation systems developed for emergency situations.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Ehime Prefecture / Nagazumi Takashi (Musician) Nagazumi visits a town with a great number of trowel reliefs, and observes that the things that truly last are the ones that carry the creator's intention.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.sub-title: History Uncovered: A Message in Clay
programme.desc: From the 3rd to the early 7th century, Japan produced terracotta figures known as haniwa in many forms. These mysterious objects hold the key to Japan's birth as a unified nation.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: This episode focuses on kuruma, which means both wheel and wheeled vehicle. A ubiquitous word, it has rolled its way into many Japanese expressions.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: On New Year's Eve, performers dress as terrifying monsters called namahage. They barge into people's homes, condemning laziness and frightening children. But this good-natured tradition strengthens family and community bonds. In Tayazawa, a small village in Akita Prefecture, the practice came to an end several years ago, but was recently restarted by an enthusiastic group of locals. They made costumes and succeeded in reviving a custom at risk of slipping away.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: JAPAN DELISH
programme.desc: Japan's longest-loved noodle dish, udon. Savor its undeniable appeal through local favorites and cutting-edge creations!

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: #34 Ensuring a Safe Journey in Japan
programme.desc: The number of foreign visitors to Japan has been on the rise since the COVID travel restrictions have been lifted. However, many are not fully aware of natural disasters that strike Japan such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and typhoons. Now, there are efforts to ensure the safety of visitors during disasters. The newly developed "announcer drone" translates text into 29 languages and instructs people to evacuate while flying. At evacuation centers, local governments are well prepared to notify important information to those who do not understand Japanese, using translation systems developed for emergency situations.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Ehime Prefecture / Nagazumi Takashi (Musician) Nagazumi visits a town with a great number of trowel reliefs, and observes that the things that truly last are the ones that carry the creator's intention.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The Young Virtuosos: Inside the Chopin Competition
programme.desc: Go behind the scenes at one of the world's top piano competitions, where joy, heartbreak, and unexpected miracles unfold as young virtuosos take the stage to embody the music of Chopin.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The Perfect 2-Hour Guide
programme.sub-title: National Museum of Nature and Science, Tokyo
programme.desc: One of Japan's largest museums, home to 25,000 exhibits spanning dinosaurs, evolution, and cutting-edge technology. Follow our two-hour ultimate route to experience its most fascinating highlights.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.sub-title: Heat and Heartbreak ― Desert Lion, Namibia
programme.desc: Charly is a solitary lioness from a long line of expert giraffe hunters in Africa's inhospitable Namib Desert. Her amazing story takes a new turn with a possible reunion with her two lost sisters.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.desc: Tokachi is in Japan's great northern land of Hokkaido Prefecture, home to vast fields and sprawling pastures. See the new leaves, brilliant yellow fields of sunflowers and clear blue skies. Experience Tokachi's vibrant summer colors through time-lapse photography.

programme.title: Let's Enjoy MATH with Barky the Dog
programme.sub-title: How Do You Make a Circle? ―Circles―
programme.desc: A toymaker is confused by Numbler and attaches the stems of his spinning tops incorrectly. Barky illustrates how to find the center of a circle by drawing diameters, and helps him properly complete the tops.

programme.title: TAKE TECH
programme.desc: Open the back of a watch, and an array of intricate parts comes into view. This episode explains how a watch accurately measures time, down to the second.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The Professionals
programme.sub-title: Going Beyond Three Stars: Kobayashi Kei, French Cuisine Chef
programme.desc: We follow French cuisine chef Kobayashi Kei, the first Japanese to earn three stars in France. Astounding the senses with the full potential of the ingredients, his dishes are praised as works of art.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef Mini
programme.desc: Dining with the Chef Mini introduces traditional techniques and resourceful recipes in just 5 minutes! Chefs Saito and Rika present their unique approaches to cooking delicious Japanese food. In this episode, we'll be making Niku-jaga: simmered meat and potatoes, using lamb and butter. Join us and learn how to make lamb Niku-jaga at home!

programme.title: The Isolado Reemerge: Unknown Depths of the Amazon

programme.title: BROADCASTERS' EYE
programme.desc: We bring you prestigious award winning programs produced by broadcasters across Japan.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Onomichi Betcha is a three-day festival in Hiroshima Prefecture. The deity of Onomichi's Ikkyu Shrine descends from a mountain, carried in a mikoshi and accompanied by three oni, or ogres. First celebrated in 1807, this matsuri began as a way to drive away an epidemic, and so the continuing impact of COVID-19 gave the event special significance in 2022. Masked figures carry sticks with which to "torment" spectators. But being hit or poked with a stick is actually said to bring good fortune.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.desc: Miura Daichi appears on tiny desk concerts JAPAN Known for his remarkable vocal ability and expressive performance style, Miura Daichi makes his debut in the intimate "tiny desk" space inside the NHK office. For this special session, he is joined by an 18-member gospel choir in a rare and powerful ensemble. In the limited space of tiny desk, the choir's overwhelming harmonies blend with Miura's fluid, soaring vocals, creating a one-of-a-kind performance that embodies the pure power of song. The uplifting energy of gospel and the subtle, breath-like nuances of Miura's singing come together to form a luxurious musical experience unique to tiny desk concerts JAPAN. At this extraordinary close distance, viewers will encounter Miura Daichi in a way they have never seen—or heard—before.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Once thought to have no dinosaur fossils, Japan is now a hot spot for dinosaur discovery. The excavation of Kamuysaurus japonicus in Hokkaido Prefecture overturned the conventional wisdom. It sparked a nationwide enthusiasm for dinosaurs that led to new forms of entertainment, including dinosaur robots in hotels and mechanical dino-suits used in live performances. We look into Japan's love for dinosaurs.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: We spend a day with the cats of Shinjuku Golden-Gai, a retro bar district in Tokyo. One cat goes on a quiet morning patrol. At night, customers visit a bar where they can drink with two cats.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: In this episode, we explore the craft of anime sound. Voice actor Otsuka Akio, who has performed in over 400 anime titles, recreates recording sessions from My Hero Academia and BLEACH: Thousand-Year Blood War, revealing the techniques behind iconic lines. We also go behind the scenes at the music recording session for the new anime Star Wars: Visions Volume 3 "The Duel: Payback," where composer Inai Keiji crafts a dramatic score that brings the visuals to life.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.sub-title: What Shelly Really Wanted to Say
programme.desc: Shelly is delighted when she is given a magical flower with an aroma that allows her to shed her shyness and state her mind. But her suddenly bold manner begins to cause undue friction. Educational theme: Friendship and mutual trust.

programme.title: u&i
programme.desc: "i" willingly cares for "u." "u" is born with short fingers, so "i" assists "u" with his personal affairs. But "u" seems unhappy. The fact is "u" has certain feelings that he is reluctant to share with "i."

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Kuala Lumpur, the capital of Malaysia, is a major urban center with a population of 2 million. Malaysia achieved independence from Britain in 1957. Following this, the Malaysian government promoted modern city development by rapidly constructing highways and housing, as well as implementing policies to nurture domestic industries. The country's economic growth continues through industrialization, such as transforming former oil palm plantations into factory sites and establishing hubs for the IT industry.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Towada-Hachimantai National Park was shaped through volcanic activity. It comprises a mystical lake, a nature-filled gorge and numerous marshes. Nature and humans have worked hand in hand to preserve this natural heritage, showcase Lake Towada's imposing beauty, and restore the bloom to Mt. Hachimantai's marshland.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: RAMEN JAPAN
programme.desc: Kyoto's ramen is rich and hearty! Step into a ramen paradise bursting with vibrant, diverse flavors.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Karesansui: A Zen Cosmos for Spiritual Training
programme.desc: A pointed boulder with a large stone at its foot reaches for the heavens. The white gravel represents a swift flowing river, without using water. Karesansui is a dry-gardening style that developed in the 14th century from ascetic practices at Zen temples. Monks meditate for enlightenment in a world of rippling patterns and curious rock arrangements. Enter the infinite Zen cosmos through Karesansui.

programme.title: Blue Whirlwind: A Ukrainian sumo wrestler
programme.desc: A 21-year-old Ukrainian whose life was drastically changed by the Russian invasion is rapidly progressing in Japanese professional sumo. In the 2025 summer tournament, he takes on the top wrestlers...

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: "They're not trash cans, but resource bins," says Murakami Yuki. His love of making goes back to childhood. And at college he developed his own banana peel leather. Transforming garbage and scrap into useful materials – lampshades from coffee grounds or chairs from old receipts – his creations are unique, but they're also as biodegradable as possible, with minimal environmental impact. This sort of alchemy has earned praise and serious interest from industries facing issues surrounding waste.
